multi_topic_discovery.topic_discovery_motivation: Impact: rates; US high‑yield savings rates reflect Fed policy stance and influence short‑term rates.

category.motivation: The article provides a market overview of high-yield youth savings account rates offered by various credit unions and banks, describing product features and competitive returns, which constitutes a market commentary on deposit products.

impact.motivation: The article discusses youth savings account APYs, which does not map to any of the canonical market handles (indices, rates, FX, commodities, credit/vol) and lacks a specific catalyst window, so it is not relevant to the graph’s focus.

time_frame.motivation: The article focuses on current product offerings and short‑term promotional rates for youth savings accounts, describing specific banks and eligibility criteria.

article_node.title: The Surprising Accounts Where Kids Can Earn 7%, 8%—Even Above 10%
article_node.summary: Kids can earn unusually high APYs—up to 10.38%—on youth savings accounts offered by select credit unions and banks, but the premium rates apply only to balances up to $1,000 (or $500 in some cases) and require a joint account with a parent or guardian. The article lists top providers such as Spectra Credit Union, Chevron Federal Credit Union, and Neighbors Credit Union, noting that membership often involves a free one‑year term with a nonprofit organization. While adult high‑yield savings accounts top out around 5%, the article also highlights that CDs and other deposit products can offer competitive returns for longer‑term investors.
